text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with blueberry shortbread bars
that's right I'm no big fan of medium
and tall bread but I do love a good
shortbread in this thanks to some
delicious sweet summer fruit is
especially delicious so let me show you
how to make this it's easy so first up
we're going to put some flour in a bowl
along with some granulated sugar some
baking powder not soda and some salt so
I decided to give that a quick stir I
want to make sure all that baking powder
is mixed in well and I'm going to take
my pastry cutter that's that wire thing
and I'm going to give that a good mix to
mix all those ingredients together and
then I'm going to spice it up a little
bit with a pinch of Chinese five-spice
you know we like to bake with this it's
very interesting quite mysterious and
borderline exotic if you're less
adventurous slash sexy go ahead and just
put in some cinnamon and nutmeg so I'm
going to mix that in and at this point
we're going to do what's called cut in
the butter so I have a stick of butter
that I cut in small cubes I put it in
the freezer for 15 minutes so it's very
nice and cold and firm and then we're
slowly going to take our pastry cutter
and cut in the butter which basically
breaks the butter into tiny tiny pieces
and yes if you have to you could use a
fork for this which is much harder and
not as good or it could use your
fingertips which is Messier and not as
good or you can use this cheap tool
which works perfectly so it's your call
either way but anyway we're going to
keep working that cutter into the butter
and flour until it looks something like
that alright and believe it or not we're
going to add one egg yolk so there's no
egg yolk in classic shortbread but I
want a little bit of richness here a
little extra moisture that's really
going to work well here because we're
doing kind of a fruit bar all right so
throw in the egg yolk cover it with
flour kind of break it up with your
pastry cutter and then just start
cutting it in and by the way when we
stop to put in the egg yolk the butter
wasn't done but we knew we were going to
work it longer when we're cutting in the
egg yolk all right so now we're cutting
in butter and egg yolk and we're going
to keep working it working it working it
until it looks like that alright at that
point we're going to add a few drops of
ice water and when I say few drops I
mean it almost literally I'm going to
drip in here about a half a teaspoon of
ice water all right and you're probably
wondering well what the heck is six or
seven drops of water going to do a lot
going to add just enough moisture to
this so I'm going to mix that in I'm
going to cut that in alright so I'm
gonna finish right there and you're
going to have a very crummy very dry
looking mixture but check it out if I
grab a handful of those crumbs and I
squeeze hard it will come together and
look like a dough but it's not really a
dough because if I give it any kind of
pressure it will just crumble right
apart alright so at that point we are
ready to transfer our shortbread mixture
into our baking dish but not all of it I
only want you to put about 75% maybe a
little less more than 2/3 with that 66%
I'm not that good at percentages I only
went to like 17 percent of my classes
but anyway dump in about 70% of the
crumbs by the way that's just a standard
square 9 inch baking dish and then with
the back of your spoon I want you to
press it down firmly okay and when all
that is pressed down very firmly and you
have a nice tight smooth surface we're
going to go ahead and add our
blueberries of course those have been
washed and pick through even though
there is a tiny stem on one of them that
I'm sure you're all staring at right now
saying man I hope he finds that all
right as far as amounts I'm not
measuring you want enough blueberries to
make a single layer where the
blueberries aren't quite touching each
other and you'll see why in a second so
that looks perfect
once the blueberries are placed in we're
going to take the rest of our shortbread
mixture and we're going to sprinkle it
over and we're going to tap it down not
quite as firm as the first layer I don't
want to crush my blueberries but do give
it a little bit of a tamping down and at
this point you do not repeat do not need
to give it the old tap a tappa
but you know what we're gonna do it
anyway alright and at that point we're
going to go into a preheated 375 degree
oven for about 30 minutes maybe 35
minutes it depends and when it's done
the top will be golden and the sides
will be sort of crisp and brown so it's
going to look like that to double check
and why I love the clear glass baking
dish is if you look on the side you're
going to definitely see that that short
bread mixture browned well so right
there I knew mine was done and then let
me know if you've heard this one before
but you have to let this cool before you
try to cut them and serve them if we try
to cut and serve this too early it will
just collapse into a pile of crumbs and
nobody wants that
but anyway we trust you let it cool
completely then cut them and serve them
and you will be extremely happy that
shortbread cookie part is going to be
kind of crisp crumbly but still tender
and buttery and then you have that
delicious fruit on top that kind of
crumbly streusel like topping really
great stuff just a great baked summer
fruit treat and if you're not into
blueberries you could use some sliced
peaches you can use apricots
blackberries lots of fun stuff so I hope
you give these a try head over to food
wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
